description.narrative: By end 2021, the government and its partners, including NGOs and communities, provide child protection services in emergency situations that conform to minimum standards, which contributes to Access To Justice, Child Protection And Emergencies, Child Protection â€“ General, Harmful Practices (Fgm/C And Child Marriage), Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 6: By the end of 2021, women, children and adolescents, especially the most vulnerable, make greater use of quality public protection services (civil registration service, juvenile justice and social assistance).

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By end 2021, the government and its partners, including NGOs and communities, provide child protection services in emergency situations that conform to minimum standards

description.narrative: In 2019, UNICEF strengthened its interventions to improve preparedness and response to child protection issues in emergencies, including adjusting its interventions to the emerging issue of children on the move. UNICEF set up community-based child protection structures, as well as child friendly spaces, to provide an integrated package of services, including psychosocial support to children affected by ongoing conflicts. UNICEF also contributed to mitigating the negative impact of armed conflict on children by supporting training of the military on child protection. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:09/02/2020

title.narrative: Number of unaccompanied and separated children who have benefitted from a formal UNICEF-supported (best interest assessment (BIA)/ best interest determination (BID) process-
Percentage of UNICEF-targeted girls and boys in humanitarian situations provided with psychosocial support, including access to child friendly spaces with intersectoral programming interventions
Percentage of UNICEF-targeted girls and boys recruited and used by armed forces and groups that have been released and reintegrated with their families and provided with adequate care and services
Percentage of UNICEF-targeted unaccompanied and separated girls and boys registered with family tracing and reunification services and family-based care or appropriate alternative services
Number of women and children in humanitarian situations who received Gender-Based Violence (GBV) response services through UNICEF-supported programmes
